Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Postoperative Perturbation Training on Gait Mechanics After ACL Reconstruction

Trial_Design.evidence: randomised to strength, agility, and secondary prevention (SAP) or SAP plus perturbation training (SAP+PERT)

Participants.evidence: Participants were recruited from a single orthopedic clinic, meeting criteria of â‰¥80% quadriceps strength symmetry, minimal knee effusion, full ROM, no pain, and completion of a running progression.

Intervention.evidence: randomised to strength, agility, and secondary prevention (SAP) or SAP plus perturbation training (SAP+PERT)

Objective.evidence: This study investigates the impact of postoperative perturbation training on gait mechanics.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Gait mechanics were evaluated at 1 and 2 years postoperatively, focusing on sagittal and frontal plane hip and knee angles and moments. The primary outcome was the elimination of gait asymmetries.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated with allocation concealment.

Number_Randomised.evidence: This randomised controlled trial involved 40 men post-ACL reconstruction

Number_Analysed.evidence: At 1 year, 11 of 18 SAP and 11 of 20 SAP+PERT athletes exhibited truncated knee excursions
